questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the inferior oblique muscle?

options.label: C
options.text: It originates from the annulus of Zinn

options.label: D
options.text: It is supplied by the third cranial nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. It originates from the annulus of Zinn
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It originates from the annulus of Zinn ANNULUS OF ZINN ( TENDINOUS RING ) TENDINOUS RING gives origin to all the rectus muscles and levator palpebrae superioris(LPS). Superior Rectus originates from the superior part of the common tendinous ring. Inferior Rectus originates from the inferior part of the common tendinous ring. Medial Rectus originates from the medial part of the common tendinous ring. Lateral Rectus originates from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring

Highyeild:

EXTRAOCULAR MUSCLES OF THE EYE: Extraocular Muscles for movement of the eyeball. The Inferior, medial, lateral, and superior recti( 4 Recti) The superior and inferior oblique muscles. (2 Oblique) Superior Rectus Attachments : Originates from the superior part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the superior and anterior aspect of the sclera. Actions : The main movement is elevation . Also contributes to adduction and medial rotation of the eyeball. Inferior Rectus Attachments : Originates from the inferior part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the inferior and anterior aspect of the sclera. Actions : The main movement is depression . Also contributes to the adduction and lateral rotation of the eyeball Medial Rectus Attachments : Originates from the medial part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the anteromedial aspect of the sclera. Actions : Adducts the eyeball Lateral Rectus : Attachment s: Originates from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the anterolateral aspect of the sclera. Actions : Abducts the eyeball. Oblique Muscles There are two oblique muscles – the superior and inferior obliques. From their origin, the oblique muscles take an angular approach to the eyeball. They attach to the posterior surface of the sclera. Superior Oblique: Attachments : Originates from the body of the sphenoid Its tendon passes through a trochlea and then attaches to the sclera of the eye, posterior to the superior rectus. Actions : Depresses , abducts and medially rotates the eyeball. Inferior Oblique : Attachments : Originates from the anterior aspect of the orbital floor. Attaches to the sclera of the eye, posterior to the lateral rectus Actions : Elevates , abducts and laterally rotates the eyeball. NERVE SUPPLY: SO4,LR6 REST BY 3RD NERVE: Superior oblique : Trochlear nerve Lateral rectus : Abducens nerve Rest by: oculomotor (III nerve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option : A. It is the shortest muscle - This is the correct statement. Option : B. Its primary action is extortion - the primary action of inferior oblique is extortion Option: D. It is supplied by the third cranial nerve - This is the correct statement.

questions.text: The best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with 15-degree accommodative esotropia of recent onset is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Refractive correction Accommodative esotropia, or refractive esotropia, is one of the most common forms of esotropia (crossed eye), which is a type of strabismus, or eye misalignment. It refers to eye crossing that is caused by the focusing efforts of the eyes as they try to see clearly. Patients with refractive esotropia are typically farsighted (hyperopic). This means that the eyes must work harder to see clearly, particularly when the object of regard is up close. Initial treatment for accommodative esotropia usually involves the prescription of eyeglasses or contact lenses to correct the patient’s refractive error (hyperopia). By letting the eyeglasses do the work, the eyes can relax their focusing or accommodative effort. In turn, this will reduce the convergence or crossing stimulus and the eyes will straighten as they relax. Glasses or contacts which are used to treat accommodative esotropia should be worn full time

Highyeild:

Visual acuity and refraction under atropine ointment The first test to be done in a patient of squint is checking for visual acuity and refraction under full cycloplegia. The cycloplegic of choice in less than 8 years is atropine ointment. The complaint of making too many mistakes points towards the blurred vision for far. Thus the foremost step is checking for refraction under cycloplegic cover. For the management of squint patients, the first & foremost step is to modestly check for refractive error with cycloplegia & correcting the same. Statement A - Correcting the refractive error corrects the squint in most of the patients. Statement B - Then the patient is trained with orthoptic exercises to strengthen the fusional reserves so that bifoveal single vision can be maintained without much effort. Statement C - Prisms are used to permanently correct the heterophoria. Prisms are better suited for vertical squints than horizontal ones. Statement D - Surgeries are the last resort when all other modalities fail. Surgery is decided according to the muscle concerned.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Orthoptic exercise - not corrective in this case. Option: B. Surgery- tried in refractory cases only. Option: C. Relieving prism - not preferred.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man came to the OPD because he had suddenly developed double vision. On examination, it was found that his right eye, when at rest, was turned medially. The most likely anatomical structures involved are:

options.label: A
options.text: Medial rectus and superior division of the oculomotor nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Inferior oblique and inferior division of oculomotor nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Lateral rectus and abducens nerve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lateral rectus and abducens nerve The lateral rectus muscle is a muscle on the lateral side of the eyeball in orbit. It is one of six extraocular muscles that control the movements of the eye. The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for the lateral movement of the eyeball, specifically abduction. Abduction describes the movement of the eye away from the midline (i.e. nose), allowing the eyeball to move horizontally in the lateral direction, bringing the pupil away from the midline of the body It is the only muscle supplied by the abducens nerve, cranial nerve VI. The abducens nerve exits the brainstem from the pons-medullary junction and travels through the superior orbital fissure to innervate the lateral rectus muscle. The lateral rectus muscle is innervated through the tectospinal tract

Highyeild:

The extraocular muscles are innervated by three cranial nerves. Damage to one of the cranial nerves will cause paralysis of its respective muscles. This will alter the resting gaze of the affected eye. Thus, a lesion of each cranial nerve has its own characteristic appearance: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) – A lesion of the oculomotor nerve affects most of the extraocular muscles. The affected eye is displaced laterally by the lateral rectus and inferiorly by the superior oblique. The eye adopts a position known as ‘down and out’. Trochlear nerve (CN IV) – A lesion of CN IV will paralyse the superior oblique muscle. There is no obvious effect of the resting orientation of the eyeball. However, the patient will complain of diplopia (double vision) and may develop a head tilt away from the site of the lesion. Abducens nerve (CN VI) – A lesion of CN VI will paralyse the lateral rectus muscle. The affected eye will be adducted by the resting tone of the medial rectus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Medial rectus and superior division of oculomotor nerve. If this muscle gets affected, the eye deviates laterally i.e., going into abduction. Option: B. Inferior oblique and inferior division of oculomotor nerve: rarely isolated palsy associated with oculomotor palsy. Option: D. Superior rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve

questions.text: Which muscle is inserted closest to the limbus of the eye?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medial Rectus Recti muscles are not inserted equidistant from the limbus and don't form a circle concentric with the limbus . Thus these muscles form a spiral (the spiral of tillaux). The medial rectus and inferior rectus are inserted 5mm and 6.5mm from the limbus. The lateral rectus and superior rectus are inserted 6.9mm and 7.7mm from the limbus respectively. Thus medial rectus is inserted closest to the limbus and the superior rectus farthest from the limbus.

Highyeild:

EXTRAOCULAR MUSCLES OF THE EYE: 6 Extraocular Muscles for movement of the eyeball. The Inferior, medial, lateral, and superior recti( 4 Recti) The superior and inferior oblique muscles. (2 Oblique) Superior Rectus Attachments : Originates from the superior part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the superior and anterior aspect of the sclera. Actions : The main movement is elevation . Also contributes to adduction and medial rotation of the eyeball. Inferior Rectus Attachments : Originates from the inferior part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the inferior and anterior aspect of the sclera. Actions : The main movement is depression . Also contributes to the adduction and lateral rotation of the eyeball Medial Rectus Attachments : Originates from the medial part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the anteromedial aspect of the sclera. Actions : Adducts the eyeball Lateral Rectus : Attachment s: Originates from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the anterolateral aspect of the sclera. Actions : Abducts the eyeball. Oblique Muscles There are two oblique muscles – the superior and inferior obliques. From their origin, the oblique muscles take an angular approach to the eyeball. They attach to the posterior surface of the sclera. Superior Oblique: Attachments : Originates from the body of the sphenoid Its tendon passes through a trochlea and then attaches to the sclera of the eye, posterior to the superior rectus. Actions : Depresses , abducts and medially rotates the eyeball. Inferior Oblique : Attachments : Originates from the anterior aspect of the orbital floor. Attaches to the sclera of the eye, posterior to the lateral rectus Actions : Elevates , abducts and laterally rotates the eyeball.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Lateral rectus: inserted 9mm from the limbus. Option: C . Superior rectus: Not the closest insertion to limbus but farthest. ( 7mm from limbus) Option: D. Inferior rectus: Not the closest insertion to the limbus. ( 6.5mm from the limbus.)

questions.text: Which two muscles constitute the superior transverse ligament of Whitnall?
questions.correct_answer: A. Levator palpebrae superioris & superior oblique
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Levator palpebrae superioris & superior oblique The superior transverse ligament of the eye (also known as Whitnall's ligament) is a transverse ligament surrounding the levator palpebrae superioris muscle close to its partial implantation into the skin of the upper eyelid . The muscle also attaches to the superior tarsal plate and into the orbital bone. It is a thickened band of orbital fascia extending from the trochlear pulley to the lacrimal gland & its fossa. It is f ormed by condensation of the superior sheaths of the levator muscle joined medially by the sheath of the reflected tendon of the superior oblique muscle . It forms a true check ligament of the levator muscle.

Highyeild:

LIGAMENTS OF ORBIT WHITNALL'S LIGAMENT This fascial sling extends from the trochlea (orbital roof, a cartilaginous pulley that contains the tendons of the superior oblique muscle) to the lateral orbit wall. It has attachments to the levator aponeurosis and the superior rectus, as well as the conjunctiva and Tenon's capsule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option : Superior rectus & superior oblique - not the correct option Option: C. Superior rectus & lateral rectus - not the correct option Option: D. Lateral rectus & medial rectus - not the correct option

questions.text: Which of these muscles form ligaments of Lockwood?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above It's a thickened sling of fascial sheath extending from the posterior lacrimal crest to the lateral orbital tubercle, on which rests the eyeball. It is formed by a fusion of expansions from the muscular sheaths of the medial rectus, inferior oblique, inferior rectus & lateral rectus muscles joined with the thickened inferior part of the tenon’s capsule.

Highyeild:

Lockwood's ligament supports the position of the globe in its position within the orbit, preventing any displacement . The globe is also supported by the medial and lateral check ligaments, septum, and adipose tissue. The course of the ligament determines the shape of the lower conjunctival fornix. It is formed by a fusion of expansions from the muscular sheaths of the medial rectus, inferior oblique, inferior rectus & lateral rectus muscles joined with the thickened inferior part of the Tenon’s capsule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. Medial Rectus All of these fuses to form lockwood ligament Option:B. Lateral rectus Option:C. Inferior rectus

questions.text: The green-coloured structure derives its nerve supply from which the nucleus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior Colliculus The muscle marked is the superior rectus. The superior rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve, the nucleus of which is situated at the level of the superior colliculus . The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of: Several groups of large motor neurons collectively called the oculomotor nucleus Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Inferior colliculus: false because involved in the auditory pathway. Option: C. Superior thalamus: sensory relay, no role in ocular motility. Option: D. Inferior thalamus: sensory relay, no role in ocular motility. Muscle Primary Secondary Tertiary Medial rectus Adduction Lateral rectus Abduction Inferior rectus Depression Excyclotorsion Adduction Superior rectus Elevation Incyclotorsion Adduction Inferior oblique Excyclotorsion Elevation Adduction Superior oblique Incyclotorsion Depression Adduction

questions.text: Rotatory movement along the anteroposterior axis in which the superior pole of the cornea moves laterally is called as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Excycloduction Excycloduction (extorsion). It is a rotatory movement along the anteroposterior axis in which the superior pole of the cornea (12 O'clock point) moves laterally (external rotation). The movements possible for the eyeball are elevation, depression, adduction, abduction, intorsion, and extorsion. These movements occur along three axes, i.e., transverse, vertical, and anteroposterior. Movement around the vertical axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as adduction and abduction . Movement around the horizontal axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as elevation and depression. Movement around the anteroposterior axis will be defined as intorsion and extorsion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Supraduction . It is upward movemen t (elevation) along the horizontal axis. Option: A . Infraduction . It is a downward movement (depression) along the horizontal axis. Option: C . Incycloduction (intorsion) . It is a rotator movement along the anteroposterior axis in which the superior pole of the cornea (12 O'clock point) moves medially (internal rotation). Excycloduction (extorsion). It is a rotatory movement along the anteroposterior axis in which the superior pole of the cornea (12 O'clock point) moves laterally (external rotation).

questions.text: The yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left Medial Rectus The yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is the left medial rectus.

Highyeild:

Yoke muscles (contralateral synergists). This refers to the pair of muscles ( one from each eye) that contract simultaneously to move the two eyes in the same direction ( version movements) . For example, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus act as yoke muscles for dextroversion movements. Other pairs of yoke muscles are: right MR and left LR, right LR and left MR, right SR and left 10, right IR and left SO, right SO and left IR and right IO and left SR.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Left Lateral Rectus- The yoke muscle of the left lateral rectus in dextroversion is the right medial rectus. Option: C. Right superior rectus - Left inferior oblique is the yolk muscle. Option: D. Right inferior oblique -Left superior rectus is the yolk muscle.

questions.text: Rajesh was posted in the ophthalmology department. The Head of the Department asks him to check the range of extraocular movements. How many cardinal fields are there?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6 There are six cardinal positions (fields) of gaze. These are the positions that allow examination of each of the twelve extraocular muscles. They are as follows: Dextroversion (right lateral rectus and left medial rectus) Levoversion (left lateral rectus and right medial rectus) Dextroelevation (right superior rectus and left inferior oblique) Levo Elevation (left superior rectus and right inferior oblique) Dextro Depression (right inferior rectus and left superior oblique) Levo Depression (left inferior rectus and right superior oblique)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . 4- No, because 6 is the correct option. Option: C. 9 - No, because 6 is the correct option, Option: D. 12 - No, because 6 is the correct option,

questions.text: A surgeon decides to relocate one or more extraocular muscles for squint surgery. Which of the following is the most common palsy surgeon can see?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6th nerve palsy Transposition refers to the relocation of one or more extraocular muscles to substitute for the action of an absent or severely deficient muscle. The most common indication is severe lateral rectus weakness due to acquired palsy of the 6th cranial nerve palsy. Isolated muscle paralysis Lateral rectus and superior oblique are the most common muscles to be paralysed singly, as they have separate nerve supplies . Isolated paralysis of the remaining four muscles is less common, except in congenital lesions. In paralysis of the right lateral rectus muscle there occurs : Overaction of the left medial rectus, Contracture of the right medial rectus and Inhibitional palsy of the left lateral rectus muscle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. 3rd Nerve Palsy: isolated palsy of the oculomotor nerve is less common. Option: B. 4th nerve palsy: less common than 6th nerve palsy. Option: C. 5th nerve palsy: causes Neuropathic keratitis.
